feed.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System

entry.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a discussion between Chris and Antoine, they explore the concept of front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Front-running is defined as entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. In the context of Bitcoin/Civkit, front-running could occur when a bulletin board operator discovers a batch of market offers and takes advantage of the opportunity before publishing the offer on its board.To illustrate this scenario, they use the example of Mary the Maker, Terry the Taker, and Bob the bulletin board operator. Mary publishes a limit order to buy a derivative, and Bob has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob doesn't want to execute, he relays the order to Terry and other subscribers to Bob's market. Terry then has the option to execute a trade against Mary's limit order. If Terry decides not to execute, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board.Antoine believes that this situation is not a significant concern because if Bob can collect outsized profits from his trusted position as the bulletin board operator, Terry will eventually move to other markets. From Mary's perspective, she is happy because her order got executed at the price she specified. However, Terry is the one who loses in this model, making it look more like a brokerage rather than an exchange market structure. Antoine suggests that Terry should open up his own brokerage (bulletin board) and compete on quoting prices with Bob. They also discuss the idea of comparing Bob and Terry on metrics like execution quality, which would draw more market activity since they would be providing better prices.Antoine mentions that front-running is actually a good problem to have because it means the market has active participants and liquidity. He emphasizes the importance of finding what products people are interested in trading and providing them with a good user experience.In terms of mitigating front-running risks, Antoine suggests two security paradigms. The first one involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards and monitoring latency anomalies. If repeated anomalies are detected, makers can disqualify the misbehaving board from future announcements. However, this approach is not perfect and still leaves room for some margin of exploitation by the boards. The second paradigm involves running the bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT or similar techniques. This would ensure consensus among federation members before publishing offers.Antoine concludes by stating that the Civkit framework proposes a flexible approach to peer-to-peer marketplaces, allowing for configuration of parameters like front-running resistance based on real-world deployments. He believes that mass front-running on the board is actually a desirable issue to have because it indicates active participants and liquidity in the market.The paper discussed in the provided context delves into the architecture of a system. The authors express their gratitude to the peer reviewers for their contributions. They also mention their plans to gradually release code and modules, building on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. These efforts are aligned with the Bitcoin open-source and decentralized standards set by Bitcoin Core. Furthermore, the authors express their eagerness to collaborate with the community in order to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients, with a long-term perspective in mind. They welcome feedback from the community.In addition to the paper, several links are provided. One link directs to an email thread discussing the paper [0]. Another link leads to the W3C recommendation for the DID Core specification [1]. A third link points to the Privacypass website [2]. Lastly, there is a link to the Lightning Dev Kit [4].Overall, the authors of the paper aim to contribute to the development and standardization of libraries in the Bitcoin community. They encourage collaboration and feedback from the community members.
